title: Inflation Issue Goes Beyond the Supply Side
sub_head: Powerful forces are fueling U.S. aggregate demand.
body:
Alan S. Blinder assures us that there is no need to worry about a return to the inflation of the past (“Don’t Worry Too Much About the Inflation Surge,” op-ed July 8). He might be less sanguine if he took into consideration the combined strength of several very powerful forces that are fueling U.S. aggregate demand.
It is not simply that this year the economy is receiving a record peacetime budget stimulus amounting to some 13% of gross domestic product at a time when the Congressional Budget Office estimates that the so-called output gap is only 3%. This massive budget stimulus is being supplemented by the easiest monetary-policy conditions in more than a decade and the drawdown of an estimated $2 trillion, or around 8% of GDP, in excess savings that were built up during the lockdown stage of the pandemic.
This makes it all too likely that, even if the current supply-side problems prove to be transitory, the economy will soon overheat under the impetus of the extraordinary amount of fiscal- and monetary-policy stimulus that it is receiving.
Desmond Lachman
American Enterprise Institute
